poem:
Title: "Ode to A Narrative of War"

In a dim lit cave of global discourse,
A man collects relics, 
Typewriter keys echo Portobello road,
Shades of a foreign ink, a Vietnamese ode.

Fifty countries etched on film and memory,
Tales of war and peace his treasury,
Oh, the saga of shifting seas and nations!
Yet morning bids us greet new iterations.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘A 1939 moment’: Jim Sciutto on Russia, China and the threat of war At CNN in Washington, Jim Sciutto’s dimly lit office is both man cave and shrine to a foreign correspondent who has reported from more than 50 countries. A typewriter he bought on Portobello Road during a decade in London. Photos he took in Afghanistan and Ukraine. A Vietnamese newspaper account of the time he rode over the South China Sea on a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
